what: Helper Functions for Linear Model Analysis
title: Helper Functions for Linear Model Analysis
text: collection helper functions multiple regression models fitted lm(). simple functions simple tasks can done coding, may easy occasional users R. information package, please visit GitHub page: https://sfcheung.github.io/lmhelprs/

title: Helper Functions for Linear Model Analysis
text: Stable release versions package can downloaded : https://github.com/sfcheung/lmhelprs/releases latest developmental version package can installed remotes::install_github:

title: Helper Functions for Linear Model Analysis
text: tasks covered sometimes needed using manymome package (Cheung & Cheung, 2023) stdmod package (Cheung, Cheung, Lau, Hui, Vong, 2022). Therefore, ready, two packages make use functions lmhelprs. However, functions can also used scenarios. Therefore, named lmhelprs.

title: Helper Functions for Linear Model Analysis
text: Cheung, S. F., & Cheung, S.-H. (2023). manymome: R package computing indirect effects, conditional effects, conditional indirect effects, standardized unstandardized, bootstrap confidence intervals, many (though ) models. Behavior Research Methods. https://doi.org/10.3758/s13428-023-02224-z Cheung, S. F., Cheung, S.-H., Lau, E. Y. Y., Hui, C. H., & Vong, W. N. (2022) Improving old way measure moderation effect standardized units. Health Psychology, 41(7), 502-505. https://doi.org/10.1037/hea0001188.

title: Helper Functions for Linear Model Analysis
text: suggestions found bugs, please feel feel open GitHub issue. Thanks.

title: Sample Data: For Testing — data_test1
text: eight-variable dataset 100 cases.

title: Sample Data: For Testing — data_test1
text: data frame 100 rows 8 variables: x1 Predictor. Numeric. x2 Predictor. Numeric. x3 Predictor. Numeric. x4 Predictor. Numeric. x5 Predictor. Numeric. y Outcome. Numeric. cat1 Predictor. String. Values: "Alpha", "Beta", "Gamma" cat2 Predictor. String. Values: "North", "South", "East", "West"

title: Sample Data: For Testing — data_test1
code: data(data_test1) lm(y ~ x1 + cat2 + cat1 + cat2:cat1, data_test1) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ x1 + cat2 + cat1 + cat2:cat1, data = data_test1) #>  #> Coefficients: #>         (Intercept)                   x1            cat2North   #>           -0.099251             0.655101            -0.510542   #>           cat2South             cat2West             cat1Beta   #>           -0.062337            -0.070097             0.003442   #>           cat1Gamma   cat2North:cat1Beta   cat2South:cat1Beta   #>            0.026172            -0.011252            -0.475115   #>   cat2West:cat1Beta  cat2North:cat1Gamma  cat2South:cat1Gamma   #>            0.140028             0.136924             0.564488   #>  cat2West:cat1Gamma   #>            0.246710   #>

title: Check Models Hierarchy — hierarchical
text: Check list 'lm' objects see whether ordered way hierarchical regression analysis.

title: Check Models Hierarchy — hierarchical
text: ... outputs lm(), , one lm-class objects. outputs model fitting functions may also used, used cautions. Please refer "works" section "Details."

title: Check Models Hierarchy — hierarchical
text: models can ordered hierarchical way, output list original lm outputs, sorted model smallest number terms model largest number terms. models ordered way, NA returned.

title: Check Models Hierarchy — hierarchical
text: Two models can compared hierarchical regression analysis one model can formed adding one terms model. function checks whether list lm outputs can ordered simplest model complex model, complex model formed adding one terms simpler model.

title: Check Models Hierarchy — hierarchical
text: extracts terms model stats::terms() extracts labels terms labels(). labels used determine hierarchical order. Therefore, principle, function can used outputs model fitting functions long outputs support stats::terms() labels can used determine hierarchical order two models.

title: Check Models Hierarchy — hierarchical
text: Shu Fai Cheung https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9871-9448

title: Check Models Hierarchy — hierarchical
code: dat <- data_test1 lm1 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2, dat) lm2 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4, dat) lm3 <- lm(y ~ x1 + cat1 + cat2 + x2 + x3 + x4, dat) lm4 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2*x3 + x4, dat)  # The order of entry does not matter hierarchical(lm1, lm4, lm2) #> [[1]] #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ x1 + x2, data = dat) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)           x1           x2   #>     -0.1231       0.6016       0.2797   #>  #>  #> [[2]] #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4, data = dat) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)           x1           x2           x3           x4   #>    -0.04715      0.41484      0.27693      0.35712      0.36060   #>  #>  #> [[3]] #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ x1 + x2 * x3 + x4, data = dat) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)           x1           x2           x3           x4        x2:x3   #>    -0.04627      0.41504      0.27698      0.35490      0.35950     -0.01706   #>  #>   # The following three models yield NA hierarchical(lm3, lm4, lm2) #> [1] NA

title: Hierarchical Regression Analysis — hierarchical_lm
text: hierarchical regression analysis two models fitted 'lm()'.

title: Hierarchical Regression Analysis — hierarchical_lm
text: call hierarchical() firsts order outputs stats::lm(), can ordered hierarchical way, passed stats::anova(). R-squared R-squared change computed available summary() method applied model. Therefore, principle, function can also used outputs model fitting functions outputs stats::anova() summary() methods.

title: Hierarchical Regression Analysis — hierarchical_lm
text: conducted hierarchical regression analysis two models fitted stats::lm(). models must able ordered simplest complex, complex model formed adding one terms simpler model. ANOVA conducted compare model next complex model order, R-squared change computed.

title: Hierarchical Regression Analysis — hierarchical_lm
text: Shu Fai Cheung https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9871-9448

title: Hierarchical Regression Analysis — hierarchical_lm
code: dat <- data_test1 lm1 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2, dat) lm2 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4, dat) lm3 <- lm(y ~ x1 + cat1 + cat2 + x2 + x3 + x4, dat) lm4 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2*x3 + x4, dat)  hierarchical_lm(lm1, lm3, lm2) #> Analysis of Variance Table #>  #> Model 1: y ~ x1 + x2 #> Model 2: y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4 #> Model 3: y ~ x1 + cat1 + cat2 + x2 + x3 + x4 #>   adj.R.sq    R.sq R.sq.change Res.Df    RSS Df Sum of Sq       F    Pr(>F)     #> 1  0.50897 0.51889    0.000000     97 55.826                                    #> 2  0.72692 0.73795    0.219059     95 30.407  2    25.419 39.7169 4.324e-13 *** #> 3  0.72698 0.75180    0.013849     90 28.800  5     1.607  1.0044    0.4199     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 hierarchical_lm(lm1, lm2, lm4) #> Analysis of Variance Table #>  #> Model 1: y ~ x1 + x2 #> Model 2: y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4 #> Model 3: y ~ x1 + x2 * x3 + x4 #>   adj.R.sq    R.sq R.sq.change Res.Df    RSS Df Sum of Sq       F    Pr(>F)     #> 1  0.50897 0.51889    0.000000     97 55.826                                    #> 2  0.72692 0.73795    0.219059     95 30.407  2   25.4190 39.3205 3.902e-13 *** #> 3  0.72423 0.73816    0.000204     94 30.383  1    0.0237  0.0733    0.7872     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 # The following models will yield an error message: tryCatch(hierarchical_lm(lm1, lm3, lm2, lm4), error = function(e) e) #> <simpleError in hierarchical_lm(lm1, lm3, lm2, lm4): The models do not have hierarchical relations.>

what: Print a hierarchial_lm Class Object — print.hierarchical_lm
title: Print a hierarchial_lm Class Object — print.hierarchical_lm
text: Print content 'hierarchical_lm`-class object.

title: Print a hierarchial_lm Class Object — print.hierarchical_lm
code: # S3 method for hierarchical_lm print(   x,   digits = 4,   signif.stars = getOption("show.signif.stars"),   eps.Pvalue = 0.001,   ... )

title: Print a hierarchial_lm Class Object — print.hierarchical_lm
text: x hierarchical_lm-class object, usually output hierarchical_lm(). digits minimum number significant digits used numbers. used print method anova-class objects. signif.stars Logical. used print method anova-class objects. eps.Pvalue passed format.pval(). controls small p-values displayed. Default .001. , p-values less .001 displayed <.001. ... Optional arguments. passed print method anova-class objects.

title: Print a hierarchial_lm Class Object — print.hierarchical_lm
text: x returned invisibly. Called side effect.

title: Print a hierarchial_lm Class Object — print.hierarchical_lm
text: printout similar print method anova object. simply overrides default values arguments, notably esp.Pvalue prevent small p-values presented scientific notation.

title: Print a hierarchial_lm Class Object — print.hierarchical_lm
text: Shu Fai Cheung https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9871-9448

title: Print a hierarchial_lm Class Object — print.hierarchical_lm
